For since the sulphureous particles, which burn at the top of a lamp, have proceeded from the wick, they must necessarily have passed through the whole ol the intermediate flame. Further,it is not to be doubted that these particles were burning from their first entrance into the dame, since the lowest partos the flame is produced only by the kindllng ol sul· ‘phureous particles. And hence it is that when a lamp ,goes out in consequence os a failure ol sulphureous nutriment, the flame is last seen at the top and at :some distance from the wick. For it is the last group -ol sulphureous particles passing through the blare, and everywhere in its transit kindling dame, that is seen at the top of the blaze. But since no sulphureous par- ticles now remain to follow these last ones, there must be an interval without flame between the last burning particles at the top of the flame and the wick.

But now the question arises why the sulphureous particles at a certain distance from the wick no longer kindleflame. And therefore there seems to be more reason for these particles, once kindled, persevering in their fiery movement and flame, than lor their entering upon a fiery movement at first.
